question: Year after year, twenty-something women come to New York City in search of the two "L's" Twenty years ago... I was one of them. Having gotten the knack for labels early... I concentrated on my search for love. Turns out, a "knock-off" is not as easy to spot when comes to love... Until it is. That is why you need help to spot them... ... Lots of help. Year after year, my single girlfriends were my salvation. And, as it turns out... ... My meal ticket. We still are those four single girls... Even though, technically... we're not. One of us is married... One of us... married, divorced and re-married... One of us... relocated. And... one of us stayed exactly where she was. In love.
answer: I got a good feeling about this one, kid.

question: I've always loved this block. Finding the perfect apartment in New York City is like finding the perfect partner. It can take years.
answer: How many does this make?

question: This is thirty-three.
answer: Lucky thirty-three!

question: And across the rooftop terrace ---
answer: What -- Nirvana?

question: Your wife has quite a sense of humor.
answer: No, he's my boyfriend.

question: Well, if the shoe fits.
answer: And this is the master bedroom.

question: Hideous. Hate it. Hurts my eyes. How is this place even available?
answer: Nasty divorce.

question: If you live here what is there to fight about? This is the master closet? No.
answer: Yes. Small for a room this size. I know.

question: Hmmm. Hmmm. Now, I understand the divorce.
answer: I can build you a better closet. Welcome home, baby.

question: Can we afford this?
answer: I got it.

question: Except for the closet which Big says he can redo -- also he says the kitchen needs work but I don't know about that `cause I keep sweaters in my stove.
answer: So, he bought it -- and you're going to live there with him?

question: Yes, together. That's right.
answer: But he'll own it. So. You are keeping your own place, right?

question: Oh, Miranda, please, I haven't figured out all the details yet, but I'm a smart girl and I'm sure I'll figure out something I'm comfortable with.
answer: I just want to make sure you're being smart here --

question: And I love you for it -- but for now can't you stop worrying for me and just go ahead and feel what I want you to feel. Jealous. Jealous of me living in this gorgeous penthouse in Manhattan.
answer: Fine. I'm jealous. You're in real estate heaven and I'm in Brooklyn.

question: There she is. Hey Hollywood!
answer: Samantha Jones... Smith Jerrod's manager -- I'm in New York `till Monday.

question: How was your flight?
answer: Fabulous. Let's go in -- I am so excited!

question: It was a rare occasion that brought all types of women together. The socialites, the trendies the yuppies, the yentas. Blair Elkenn was a waitress turned model turned actress turned billionaire's girlfriend who came home one night to find herself unceremoniously turned out on the street. And now she was getting the ultimate break-up revenge. An embarrassing and very public auction of all the jewelry he had given her when they were happy.
answer: There it is. My baby. When I saw this in the catalogue I said to Smith

question: And a little too much.
answer: Exactly. Come on. Let's go spend some of my hard-earned Hollywood money.

question: Thirty-five. Forty?
answer: I deserve this. I work hard.

question: Do I hear forty? Do I hear forty fi-- Fifty?
answer: Sex with only one man for I don't know how long.

question: Do I hear fifty thousand?
answer: Fifty fucking thousand!

question: Fifty-five? Sixty? Sixty to our colorful bidder?
answer: I draw the line at fifty.

question: The creatures are ready. Just gonna sit there?
answer: I'm not sitting, I'm thinking.

question: Here. Husk and think.
answer: I'm thinking I'm going to sell my apartment and put the money towards heaven on Fifth.

question: Why? You love your place.
answer: I know but --

question: But what?
answer: We're together ever night -- so I'm basically paying a mortgage on a glorified closet.

question: You write there. It's your office.
answer: There's plenty of room at the new place and -- besides.. I want to make us -- a life there. I want it to be ours.

question: It is ours. I bought it for us.
answer: And that's so amazing --but you bought it, so it's really your place. And -- if anything were to happen...

question: What's going to happen?
answer: I have to be smart here. I mean, we're not married and I'd have no legal rights to... this home that I built... with you.

question: Did you want to get married?
answer: I didn't think it was an option.

question: Well, Mr. Bradshaw, what if it was an option?
answer: Well, people are always assuming we are.

question: And you know what happens when people assume. They make an ass out of who?
answer: You and me.

question: What do you think, kid?
answer: Why -- Do you want to get married?

question: Well, I wouldn't mind be married to you. Would you mind being married to me?
answer: No, if that's what you want. Is that what you want?

question: I want you. So. Okay.
answer: Okay. Really? We're getting married.

question: We're getting married. Should we get you a diamond?
answer: No, please, don't get me a diamond. Get me a really big closet.

question: Deal. But... You gotta do better on that corn. Look at all the stuff left on there.
answer: So, the other night, Big and I were talking about, you know, moving in together and our future... ... And about what makes sense as we move forward. And, well... we decided to get married.

question: Samantha Jones--
answer: Well... I made a little decision that I hope you'll be happy about.

question: Oh, honey... you finally got Botox.
answer: No. I did not get Botox

question: I'm telling you, Carrie -- you'll love it.
answer: I did not call to talk about Botox.

question: I'm just saying.
answer: So... Last week, after the auction, I started thinking about my options.

question: Right.
answer: Right, and... well, Big and I decided to get married.

question: Really?
answer: Yes.

question: That's great.
answer: You sounded more excited about the botox.

question: Well, honey -- I am excited for you but -- you know me... I don't really believe in marriage.... Botox on the other hand -- That works every time. Honey, I've got to go. The People magazine person is on hold. Smith's on the short list to be their "Sexiest Man Alive." We can catch up when I'm in town next week.
answer: Hello?

question: I think I was in shock. I mean, it's you getting married. This is not some random person -- it's you.
answer: I hear ya.

question: And I guess, I thought that after that big mess with Aidan -- you'd never want to get married.
answer: I know.

question: So, I put you in my "we're never getting married" file. Now, I've got to take you out of that file.
answer: Sorry about the extra paper work.

question: You'll get my bill.
answer: Samantha, it feels so different this time. No clich romantic kneeling down on one knee. Just you know, two grown-ups -- making a decision about spending their lives together.

question: Well, I'm happy for you.
answer: And one more thing... I want you to be maid of honor. How do you feel about that?

question: Simple and classic. When I saw it I just thought
answer: Well, who's it by? The label?

question: No one. I found it in a vintage shop.
answer: "The bride wore a dress by no one."

question: Don't worry, I'll style it up with shoes.
answer: The invitation is fancier than the dress.

question: What? I'm sorry. I'm exhausted. Brady woke me up at five AM.
answer: He woke me up too. You got milk on your top lip. What now?

question: It's like you're always criticizing me.
answer: I am not. You want to go through life with foam on your lip and no one telling you? Anything you want to tell me?

question: Yeah. Yeah.
answer: Wait --- wait -- Don't come already...

question: Yeah. Yeah.
answer: Wait, wait -- get on top. Get on --

question: It's late... let's just get it over with. I mean -- We have to get up in four and half hours.
answer: We never have sex and you want to get it over with?

question: Steve... We have sex.
answer: When was the last time we had sex? There was snow on the ground.

question: Steve and I were "coloring" last night and just as I was about to --
answer: Come? Sorry -- there is no crayon equivalent.

question: He wanted to change positions and I said... "Let's just get it over with." Well, he kept trying to make it last longer.
answer: And this is bad?

question: It is when you have a full-time job.
answer: I have a full-time job.

question: Send it to Smith Jerrod at the office address. I've got to go. Something just came up.
answer: I've got a gift for you.

question: So far, I like it. How did -- Wait -- that was you on the phone at the auction?
answer: I knew how much you wanted it.

question: But I was going to buy it for myself.
answer: I wanted to give it to you... for our anniversary. We met five years ago today.

question: Right.
answer: Do you like it?

question: To be clear -- This is a ring with diamonds -- not a diamond ring, right? In that case... I love it. It's my second favorite thing I've ever found in there. Now, my gift's a little bit more... oral.
answer: Babe -- I've got to go to bed.

question: Bed? It's seven-thirty.
answer: I have to be at the studio by six A.M. and I need to get a workout before that.

question: This is how it starts. Next thing you know... we're only having sex three or four times a week.
answer: Most people consider that normal.

question: I am not most people.
answer: No - you most certainly are not.

question: One glass of Merlot and two orgasms later. And that is how Samantha learned she had a new neighbor. John? Lean?
answer: Are you the last person in New York still taking out library books?

question: I love the smell.
answer: That's an old one.

question: "The Love Letters of Great Men." Volume one.
answer: Am I in there?

question: No, but some of your classmates are. Voltaire, Napoleon...
answer: You need to get glasses.

question: No, I don't -- you have them. Here's Napoleon... "My dearest Josephine, I wake consumed with thoughts of you --"
answer: Typical short guy. Gives it all away up front. Why are you reading this?

question: Research for my new book.
answer: What's it about?

question: Love. I use to write about finding love-- now I want to write about what happens after you've found it.
answer: Interesting. What happens?

question: Stay tuned. Listen... Here's Beethoven.
answer: Bring it, Ludwig.

question: "My thoughts go out to you today my immortal beloved. I can live only wholly with you or not at all."
answer: Good stuff.

question: "Be calm my life, my all. Only by calm consideration of our existence can we achieve our purpose to live together. Oh continue to love me, never misjudge the most faithful heart of your beloved. Ever thine -- ever mine -- ever ours. Have you ever written me a love letter?
answer: Does a love fax count?

question: When have I ever gotten a love fax?
answer: I'm pretty sure my secretary sent one at some point. What can I say, baby? Not my style. Besides, these guys had to write-- they were separated from their loves by wars and hundreds of miles. I'm right here. Hi. You make me very happy.

question: Yeah, yeah.... Put it in writing.
answer: Alright. Here's a love letter from me to you. Loving you. Is easy... `cause your beautiful...

question: I've been thinking.
answer: Again?

question: How about we get married at The New York Public Library? Think how perfect. You and I and our love story surrounded by all the other lesser love stories.
answer: Do we have to make that big of a deal?

question: It's not that big a deal. It's seventy-five people in a room that's partitioned in half.
answer: It's just -- I've already had two big weddings.

question: Well, what did you have in mind?
answer: I don't know -- a judge, couple friends and then we go for ham and eggs after.

question: Interesting.
answer: Would we have to whisper? In the library? "Do you, Carrie" -- Shhhh. "Take this man" -- SHHHH!

question: Carrie, hi!
answer: Elaine, hi. Do you know John?

question: No, hi. Nice to meet you.
answer: Elaine writes a single gal column for The New York Post.

question: Please -- I'd rather you reveal my weight.
answer: Well. We're getting married.

question: Oh, I know who. Later that day, I met my friend Stanford for our weekly quick lunch and gossip session... Also known as "dish then dash."
answer: According to a certain trashy tome, you are marrying John James Preston.

question: Rumor has it.
answer: Just one question

question: Where are we eating?
answer: Anywhere you like... and you know the rule -- the person on Page Six pays for lunch.

question: It seemed everywhere I went... people I knew were excited and available to come to the wedding.
answer: You forgot to charge us for the gaggle of gays.

question: The shocking thing was not the plethora of empty autumn social calenders but knowledge that everyone does indeed read Page Six. Even people you didn't expect, like my Vogue editor, Enid.
answer: We're putting together our annual "Age" issue -- and we'd like you to do forty.

question: Great. Who am I interviewing?
answer: No. You. You are forty. I want you to be featured in the magazine as the forty year old -- and here's the brilliant twist -- bride.

question: Wait -- I would be in the magazine?
answer: In bridal couture. It's a once in a lifetime opportunity - so spare me a week of faux soul-searching and just say yes.

question: Enid -- I'm so very flattered but--
answer: Carrie. Vogue designers, Vogue photographers, Vogue airbrushing. Nod your head Thank-you. It will be a sensation. We're calling it

question: Well, I'm hardly the last single girl.
answer: No, but forty is the last age you can see a woman photographed in a wedding gown without the unintended Diane Arbus subtext.

question: I thought the issue was "great style at every age."
answer: Style yes... bride no.

question: Enid -- I have no idea -- were you ever married?
answer: Briefly. In 1975. I wore Halston. Creme. One shoulder Grecian with a low-cut bodice to the waistline for a dramatic flair. The fabric in the sleeves formed oval draping on the sides. Stunning. My future husband and I saw it on a trip to Paris and he fell in love with it. Insisted I be married in it. So I was. We had quite a beautiful party.

question: Why didn't the marriage work out?
answer: Did you not hear me say my husband fell in love with my gown? Has your fiance expressed any interest in what you'll be wearing?

question: None at all.
answer: Then you may have a shot.

question: Just your typical Wednesday. Breakfast with... Vera Wang. Mid-morning coffee with.... Carolina Herrera. Appetizers with Oscar de la Renta. Lunch with Lanvin... ... And Lacroix. ... And Dior. And for dessert -- Vivienne Westwood. A confection so special... ... It could wring a wedding tear from even the most unbelieving of women. And then the impossible happened. And just like that, Vivienne Westwood kicked my sweet little suit's ass.
answer: Okay. Open them.

question: Double door. So far so good. Well. You did me proud, Mister.
answer: Like it?

question: It's a sign.
answer: Yeah, a sign I priced it too low. That's the food -- money on the table. I'll get started in the closet... I should be done in seventeen years.

question: Pink Post-it -- take. Purple -- toss. Yellow
answer: You're good friends.

question: Samantha! Oh my God!
answer: What are you doing here?!

question: Oh, you know me -- I'm your daughter-in-law. I'm Miranda. While I run over to see your mother tomorrow maybe you can take him to the first birthday party alone. Then -- I'll meet you at the twins' party and you can leave and be at the bar by six. What's the matter? Steve.
answer: -- I had sex with someone else. -- And you are so amazing with Ma and everything... everything you do and I can't believe I would do that to you. You and I hadn't had sex in a really long time and I -- It didn't mean anything -- It was just once... and it's been killing me.

question: It's killing you?!
answer: It just happened... I wasn't thinking.

question: Do not follow me.
answer: Hi.

question: Surprise -- Here we are!
answer: Well, I'm so excited you are here for a sleepover.

question: We are too. Aren't we B-boy? Here. Mommy has to go to the bathroom.
answer: Brady, do you want to go have some peanut butter?

question: Is it?
answer: So Miranda left Brooklyn and came home... to Manhattan.

question: Yes, it's sad, but I'm not going to make it any sadder by staying at a bad hotel while I look for a place. Pass the salt. Plus, I have to be downtown and close to Brooklyn. We're going to keep things as normal for Brady as we can. I'll pick him up on my days... take him over on Steve's.
answer: I don't know if this question is allowed -- but how is Steve handling this?

question: It's a little quick to move out, don't you think?
answer: Her reaction is her reaction. Thanks Anaka.

question: He had sex once. Not even an affair.
answer: Maybe it's not the sex. Maybe, it's the cheating. For me... that would be the thing. That it happened behind my back.

question: That's what she said.
answer: Look. I know we're not married but - - if you were going to have sex with someone else...

question: Are you waiting for me to get out my datebook?
answer: But... seriously, I'd rather know first.

question: You want me to tell you if I'm going to have sex? Fine. I'm about to have sex.
answer: Thanks Anaka.

question: Miranda was starting to see the upside of Alzheimer's. Wedding crunch time. We need to really get serious here.
answer: Not now -- I just got an email from the the contractor -- they pushed our move-in date again -- and I have to --

question: Nope. Wedding before contractor. Unless you're planning to invite him -- which would make the guest list two hundred and one.
answer: Two hundred? Jesus, Carrie -- it's gone up again?

question: Blame the New York Post and Vogue. Two publications that have never before been uttered in the same sentence.
answer: You said

question: It's the dress. How can I explain this? It's like poker -- The dress upped the ante.
answer: Change the dress.

question: No, no, no -- you haven't seen this dress. This dress may be the whole reason to get married. Well, you and the dress. How are you coming with your vows? Just a reminder -- you are going to be saying these in front of a lot of people, so the pressure is on.
answer: Up, up. I have to finish this. Up.

question: Hey...
answer: I don't have time for this.

question: This is our wedding and you're not taking it seriously.
answer: No, I'm not -- It's a circus! Two hundred people -- Page Six -- This is my third marriage -- how do you think it makes me look?

question: I didn't know that was even an issue. Why didn't you say anything sooner?
answer: You wanted all this.

question: But -- don't you want --
answer: I want you, Carrie. That's what I want. I would have just gone down to city hall.

question: I think it's too late for city hall now.
answer: Well, no. I wasn't suggesting -- I was just saying. See. That is the face I've been trying to avoid. Come here.

question: Karl's kind of a jerk.
answer: Hey "dick wad"... I'm speaking.

question: Whooo!
answer: Now. There were times when we had our doubt about this gorgeous man. But after careful observation over the last hundred years, my doubts are over. So... here's to the groom. A man who finally got "Carrie-d" away.

question: Could you give us --
answer: You didn't leave me any choice. You won't return my calls -- You only talk to me in front of the baby when you know I can't say anything.

question: What could you possibly have to say that could make it better?
answer: Miranda, please... It was just that one time. Please -- I love you --

question: There you are. I thought you skipped out on me. Well, the all-gal sleepover is about to commence. You gonna miss me?
answer: Don't go. Spend the night with me.

question: Oh... One night won't kill you. And tomorrow you get to have me for the rest of your life. Is everything okay?
answer: I'm just tired -- I guess.

question: Hello?
answer: It's me.

question: Oh my God -- did you just hear Lily?
answer: Hey -- I need to talk. I'm sitting here trying to write these vows and... Is this something we really want to do?

question: What's the matter?
answer: It's just -- everything is great as it is. I don't want to screw it up.

question: You won't.
answer: I screwed it up twice before.

question: Here's the thing. This is me that you're marrying tomorrow. Me. Nobody else.
answer: Yeah.

question: And I'm marrying you. It's me and you. And you want to know the good news there?
answer: Yeah.

question: We've already both done everything we can to screw it up. Is that a smile I'm hearing?
answer: Yeah.

question: Now, it sounds to me like you've got a bit of writer's block on the vow front.
answer: Yeah.

question: And I find - you know - as a professional writer- it's best to just, you know, stop thinking about it so much -- and go to bed. And in the morning...
answer: You know what to do?

question: Exactly. And if not -- Just write this You're going to bed now, right?
answer: Okay. Good night.

question: We have a problem.
answer: I know, but for Carrie's sake I've decided to ignore your attitude.

question: No, a real problem. They're not here.
answer: They're probably stuck in traffic.

question: Did anyone call him? Give me a phone. Someone give me a phone. I don't know how to work this. Are you okay?
answer: I've been calling you for an hour. Why haven't you been answering your phone?

question: I don't know where my phone is! What is going on? Where are you?
answer: I was out front --but I just left. I can't do this.

question: What the fuck am I doing? What the fuck am I doing? Turn around and go back. By the time we go around the block she'll be gone. No one's behind us - - Turn around! Pull over. Pull over. Carrie! I freaked out for a minute -- but -- I'm ready now -- Carrie!
answer: I knew you would do this -- I knew it!

question: I'm sorry -- I just --
answer: You left! I am humiliated!

question: I thought I would still be in extreme pain but I'm feeling nothing. I'd like a little more nothing. I had gone from Little Women to Little Drunk Women. Yes, I'm still jilted.
answer: What the hell got into him? He was perfectly fine at the dinner.

question: I knew it when he called last night. I could tell.
answer: Why didn't you say anything?

question: Didn't want to believe it. Didn't even want to say it out loud. And now I have nowhere to love -- I meant live. I have nowhere to live.
answer: You'll stay here.

question: Forever.
answer: Maybe you should eat something. Anyone hungry?

question: I did something really bad -- I think. I said something to Big. At the rehearsal dinner.
answer: What do you mean?

question: It was right after Steve showed up. I was upset... Big came up to me -- and I said something like Do you think it was totally the reason?
answer: No, no, no. Big has been weird about marriage for years.

question: I keep thinking I should tell Carrie.
answer: No, no. This is a really bad time to even mention it - no, no, no. Find another time. Later.

question: Well, turns out, I couldn't get her out of the honeymoon -- but I got us in.
answer: What?

question: I just booked us three seats on the flight. Mexico here we come.
answer: I can't go to Mexico. I have a job.

question: I forgot to get a wax.
answer: Since when -- 1998?

question: I've had other things on my mind.
answer: I could be on death row and not have that situation.

question: Well, when you're married, Samantha -- you have a different set of priorities.
answer: Honey don't blame marriage -- This one's married -- and she's not growing a national forest. How do you even cross your legs? Let me make you a spa appointment -- Any thicker and you won't be able to find it.

question: So what -- It's my fault?! I let the sex go out of our marriage! I deserve what I got. Thanks for understanding.
answer: Honey, I'm sorry. That's not what --

question: I'll drink hers. We're staying in one of the private houses. Number three. That was like taking a bullet.
answer: Charlotte had pudding in her Prada.

question: Will I ever laugh again? I'm serious.
answer: Yes.

question: When?
answer: When something is really, really funny.

question: Even this ring. I wanted to buy this for myself. That meant something to me. To be able to do that. Then, he buys it for me.
answer: Because he knew how much you loved it.

question: Yes. But now, every time I look down at it... I see him. Not me.
answer: You could look at it and see a man who loves you and wants you to be happy.

question: No, you could look at it and see that. I'm Samantha. We'll take another round.
answer: Another?

question: Technically -- we're on my honeymoon.
answer: No-- I think we're on their honeymoon. It's all so hot -- three days in.

question: He couldn't get out of the car. After everything he'd already put me through -- he couldn't make the effort and get out of the car? I made the effort -- I put a bird on my head.
answer: Was that what that was?

question: Yes.
answer: I thought it was just feathers.

question: Well, apparently you can go home again -- but it'll cost you.
answer: Now -- lets work on getting your things there.

question: You two could rule the world. After her workout Charlotte couldn't help but think about how truly blessed she was. This week had made her feel more grateful than ever for her happy marriage. And while picturing her loved ones at home in New York, she forgot where she was... And opened her mouth. Sweetie -- what's --
answer: That's locked -- Use the other--

question: There was no better time I could think of to hire and assistant. Um, Cathy... You seem drunk. And why do you think you're right for this job? So, you're from St. Louis?
answer: That's right. Louise from St. Louis.

question: Have you ever been a personal assistant?
answer: No, but I'm the oldest of six kids, so I can pretty much handle anything you got.

question: Six kids? What was that like?
answer: Crowded. I had to move to New York just to get some room. And where'd I wind up? A one bedroom apartment with three roommates.

question: Aside from the space issue... why'd you move to New York?
answer: To fall in love. What? That's corny, right?

question: No, it's just -- so -- honest. I don't think I've ever heard anyone say that in a long time. Well... Louise from St. Louis... I have just one more question. How does an unemployed girl with three roommates afford the Patchwork Denim Bowley Louis Vuitton bag?
answer: It's rented. "Bag, Borrow or Steal." It's like Netflix for purses.

question: No! How can I not know about this?
answer: Girl, stick with me, I'll hook you up.

question: And she did hook me up.
answer: Carrie Bradshaw... This is Louise. Anne From the New York Observer... I'll let her know you called.

question: No, I can't be more patient. Your agency has had three weeks to find me an apartment. No -- I told you... It has to be in Manhattan. Because it does. How hard could it be to find something just on the other side of the Brooklyn Bridge? On second thought -- Forget it. I could do a better job myself. According to New York Magazine, this is the new up-and-coming neighborhood. See! Wherever he's going is where we need to be.
answer: I've been here before -- This was all Ukrainian area.

question: Coming or going? Going. Oh boy. Lets go. Hi. I'm interested in the apartment. I understand but -- who would I talk to about it? Lovro... -- and I have no idea. Ku...
answer: Kljuic. Lovro Klujcik. I know him.

question: No way.
answer: We were couple -- long time ago.

question: No way -- You dated?
answer: Haven't seen him since his wife died.

question: That was really hot.
answer: Hmmm. You were kind of distant.

question: Distant? You're still in me.
answer: You want to talk about it?

question: When have I ever wanted to talk about it?
answer: Okay. I'll talk about it. Your best friends get screwed over by their guys -- how can you not get distant?

question: It's more than that -- lately, I haven't been feeling a connection to --
answer: What? Me?

question: No -- to -- it -- here. I have no real connection to our life here.
answer: What life here? Seriously -- all I do is work -- and you run off to New York every chance you get.

question: Not every chance I get. Only for the A-list things. And my managing you -- it's all too much. I'm starting to resent it. For the last two years it's been all about you.
answer: Well, for the first three years it was all about you.

question: I know. That was so much more fun.
answer: Maybe we need to make an effort to reconnect -- spend more time together -- away from the business. Less me, less you -- More us.

question: So, I won't be coming to New York for a while. We're going to spend some time reconnecting on the weekends... do the "LA couple thing."
answer: Yeah, hi, can you put on Samantha?

question: Really. At first I was all
answer: You people and your relationships.

question: Honey, a pay phone? Where's your cell?
answer: At the bottom of the ocean in Mexico.

question: Want me to hook you up with a new one?
answer: No, not yet. No phone -- no calls, no calls-- no questions, no questions-- no explaining no wedding. Plus, It's an excuse to break out the gloves. When Samantha Jones decides to do something... ... She does it all the way. She and Smith did all the upscale L.A. couple things. Sushi... ... Spray tanning. ... And saving Somalia... Samantha- style.

question: No, not yet. No phone -- no calls, no calls-- no questions, no questions-- no explaining no wedding. Plus, It's an excuse to break out the gloves. answer: Carrie Bradshaw's web page is a mess.

question: -- Interesting -- so is Carrie Bradshaw. Come on -- When are we going to get to the really important things like unpacking my closet?

question: Now?
answer: Okay -- I'll read -- you tell me what to do. Vitaminsforless. Delete. Right?

question: So right.
answer: Who's John@jjpny.com.? Oh, shit -- that's him, right?

question: Delete. And -- isn't there some cyberspace place that you can send those so that I never have to see an email from him ever again? Do that please.
answer: You sure you want to end all communication with him?

question: Thanks for watching her while I went to the doctor.
answer: Sure. Everything okay?

question: I'm pregnant.
answer: How?

question: My doctor said sometimes when women stop trying -- it can happen. She knows other couples that adopt and then get pregnant.
answer: Sweetie.

question: Carrie -- I'm pregnant!
answer: I guess, in certain houses, fairy tales do come true. I can't believe you're even dressing up.

question: I guess, in certain houses, fairy tales do come true. I can't believe you're even dressing up.
answer: All the parents at Brady's school dress up -- it's fun! Fun thought up by a group of non-working mothers with nothing else to do all day. Witch and -- "sexy kitten". That's it? The only two choices for women. Witch and Sexy kitten.

question: You said a mouthful there, sister.
answer: Maybe I should just wear this and a business suit and go as myself.

question: Speaking of monsters -- I got an email from Big. "I don't know what to say." Ah... then don't send an email.
answer: What were you expecting?

question: Gonna take a little more than that to scare me after what I have been through. And in the subject box
answer: Steve is all about "I'm sorry." I'm sorry emails -- I'm sorry voice mails -- I'm sorry flowers -- I'm sorry cards. How about

question: Maybe he's sorry.
answer: Maybe Big is too.

question: Point taken. I still can't believe this happened to me. I know it happened, but I can't believe it happened. I lay awake at night going over every detail of the last week in my head.
answer: Carrie -- There's a detail I've been meaning to tell you about --

question: And then I saw it...the only thing scary enough to scare me after the experience I'd been through.
answer: You look great, you look amazing. So. That's the worst of it.

question: Wait -- what's that say? In the box at the end?
answer: "Editor's note

question: Is what? "Carrie Bradshaw is still single and living in Manhattan." I didn't want to buy it - but I figured it was one less Vogue in New York.
answer: I saw it. The pictures are gorgeous.

question: Yes -- I'm a beautiful bride. Come in.
answer: Look, the people who don't know -- will only see the beautiful pictures. The people who do know will only see what an asshole he is. Mommy said a bad word.

question: Cinderella.
answer: Or -- we also brought Mulan. Would you like to go trick or treating with us?

question: Yea!
answer: Just in our building -- if you feel up to it.

question: Look closer. I'm the scariest thing in New York. Jilted at Forty-one. Boo. You know you have to give me some of your loot, right? Louise!
answer: Oh my Lord. I did not even recognize you.

question: That's the point. My head is the witness protection program.
answer: I'm really feeling that look on you.

question: And I am feeling that Balenciaga on you.
answer: Mine till Tuesday. Here -- time to re-join the world.

question: Already?
answer: Your new number... area code

answer: No longer available. Now, you're

question: Great. Now even I don't recognize me.
answer: Samantha Jones.

question: Carrie Bradshaw -- -- Or I used to be.
answer: Talk to me.

question: I'm a 347 area code. How tacky is that?
answer: 347 is the new New York.

question: I want the old New York with the old 917 and my old will to live.
answer: Old New York, new New York -- honey -- at least it's New York. Another hard thing about being in L.A? My "sex on a stick" next door neighbor. I can't stop looking at him.

question: Looking?
answer: Just looking. After I saw Steve's face at the rehearsal dinner, I could never --- But you should see this guy. Every night sex with a different partner. He's like -- --Me. Five years ago.

question: Yes. When I was a 212. And in an effort to stay out of her house and out of trouble -- Samantha went shopping. It certainly wasn't the cutest dog in the pen - but their was something about it -- And just as Samantha convinced herself that the dog wasn't for her.
answer: And she needs a little eye work. Anything you can do about these stains? Honey, I don't mince words.

question: Do you want me to get rid of it?
answer: No, it's too beautiful. I'll just bury it deep in the back -- like I did my feelings.

question: Do you miss him?
answer: Every day. You know, it's weird -- I haven't cried very much at all. Maybe you're only allotted a certain amount of tears per man -- and I used mine up.

question: Yeah. I know how you feel `cause, my college boyfriend broke up with me last year. And I miss him all the time.
answer: Suddenly, it dawned on me -- there were two broken hearts in my-walk in. Louise -- we need a cocktail. Grab your rental.

question: And it threw me so hard `cause, you know, I thought Will -- that's his name... was the love of my life.
answer: What happened?

question: He said he loved me and all -- but didn't think I was "the one". And that hurt. But -- you know -- whatever. I'm not going to give up on love.
answer: Good.

question: Love is the thing, you know. See that. I'm bringing it to me all day long.
answer: Oh, I remember that smile. Who's the guy?

question: Someone I just met. He wants me to meet him for a drink.
answer: At 11:30? That's a bootie call.

question: No, it's not like that... he just got off work -- he's a waiter.
answer: Louise, I may not get texts and I may not send texts -- but trust me

question: But it's not a bootie call if he meets me.... right?
answer: All right, then. You kids enjoy. That's what your twenties are for. Your thirties are to learn the lessons. And your forties are to pay for drinks.

question: You going for your run?
answer: Um... no.

question: You didn't go yesterday either.
answer: I know.

question: Why is that?
answer: I don't feel like running!

question: It's all about the desk. If I find the desk, the writing will come. And it better `cause I'm using my new book advance to pay the fancy decorator.
answer: I think it's so great that you are re-doing your entire apartment.

question: Out with the old -- -- In with the overpriced. Hey, Harry called me and mentioned you're not running.
answer: Why'd he do that?

question: `Cause he loves you... and he's concerned.
answer: There is nothing to be concerned about.

question: Did the doctor say it wasn't safe or something?
answer: No, she said because I'm already a runner -- it's fine.

question: So, why are you not --
answer: I'm afraid something bad will happen. It's a miracle that I'm even pregnant.

question: But if the doctor said --
answer: It's not rational, Carrie... it's irrational. I know that.

question: Okay.
answer: I've got everything I ever wanted. I'm so happy -- I'm terrified. No one gets everything they want. Look at you. Look at Miranda. You're such good people and look what happened to you. Of course, something bad is going to happen to me.

question: Sweetie, you shit your pants this year. Maybe you're done. You run every day -- that's what you do. You can't stop being who you are -- just because you're afraid. Right? Now let's get down to business. I've got to have my apartment done in time for that baby shower. And as the last of the autumn leaves fell away -- so did Charlotte's fear.
answer: You sure you don't want me to RSVP to some of these holiday parties?

question: Yep. I'm perfectly happy spending time home alone. And speaking of home -- you're going to miss your plane.
answer: Merry Christmas. It's just something silly.

question: Oh... Louise from St. Louis.
answer: You said you never saw it -- so.

question: Now, I feel bad. If I had known we were going to exchange gifts -- I would have bought you one two weeks ago and hidden it in here.
answer: No! That is not what I think it is.

question: Open it.
answer: Oh my Lord. Oh my --

question: No more rent girl for you.
answer: Look who's home from the big city!

question: And what are you gonna say at midnight?
answer: Happy New Year.

question: That's right -- but you gotta say it more excited than that -- "Happy New Year!"
answer: Happy New Year!

question: You say that and then... you kiss.
answer: You all ready to go, B-boy?

question: Did you pack the new Batman Santa brought you?
answer: Aw man -- Gotta have the new Batman.

question: It's there near the tree.
answer: You got plans with the girls?

question: We're all kinda staying in tonight.
answer: Would you like to come and eat with us? We can go somewhere over here on your side.

question: No, thank you.
answer: Miranda -- I never meant to hurt you.

question: There he is. Batman.
answer: Put your hat on. It's snowing out. Happy New Year.

question: Hello?
answer: Happy New Year -- We're having a fabulous time. The only thing missing is you. Come.

question: That's sweet but I can't, I'm writing.
answer: Oh... Okay. You're not really writing are you?

question: No. You're not really having a fabulous time are you?
answer: No. Rescue me. It's very forced festive.

question: Oh yes, that's just what every New Year's Eve party needs
answer: Well... Better a Bronte sister than a Hilton sister.

question: Thanks but -- by ten PM I'll be in bed asleep and blissfully unaware of how fabulous this night is supposed to be. Hello.
answer: I thought one of the perks of having a family is you don't have to spend New Year's Eve alone with Chinese food. I'm alone with Chinese food.

question: I was sleeping.
answer: Oh, shit -- I'm sorry.

question: That's okay. Where's Brady?
answer: It's Steve's night.

question: Right.
answer: Go back to sleep -- don't wake up.

question: It's okay. Are you alright?
answer: I'm fine -- I was just getting a little choked-up watching the stupid New Year's Eve stuff on TV alone.

question: Want me to come over?
answer: I'm all the way downtown --

question: I can grab a cab --
answer: On New Year's Eve? No way. I'm fine... really. I just wanted to talk a little. Go back to sleep. Good night.

question: No, see -- I've always had girlfriends on the side.
answer: There's Mayor Bloomberg.

question: New Yorkers are so damn attractive - - Even the Mayor is hot.
answer: I believe that was his last campaign slogan.

question: Are you suggesting something?

question: And are you also suggesting that she forgive Big?

question: Impressive. Better work up a hand gesture to go with it.
answer: Thank god you're here. They have me covering this Mercedes-Benz fashion week and I'm desperate for a Carrie Bradshaw-esque quote.

question: Well, I'll do my best. We'll talk after?
answer: Great. And -- ooh -- my back -- -- Can I just say that I'm so sorry about what happened with your wedding. I don't know how you survived it. I, personally, was so devastated I took myself off JDate -- but you survived and you're here and you look amazing and I just think that's so great. Everyone in my row does -- we can't stop talking about it. Okay -- Meet you in the lobby after.

question: Carrie, wait.
answer: This was a mistake -- it's too soon -- I'm not ready. I'll go get a coffee and you guys call me after -- and I'll meet you for lunch.

question: Are you sure? I know how much you were looking forward to this.
answer: Yeah, I really was... until I became the poster child for wounded women everywhere.

question: You're not.

question: No -- but if you leave right now -- it will effect the rest of your day. It's Fashion Week. We're in the front row.
answer: Where everyone can see me.

question: We thought we were leaving.
answer: I didn't know if it was the fashion or the fact that the four of us were together again -- but for the first time in a long time -- I felt like myself.

question: Let's get a cab -- I am starv -- God, I miss New York.
answer: And a couple of weeks later -- I met St. Louise's St. Louis boyfriend, Will. Over Christmas they realized how much they loved each other. Just in time for Valentine's day. Hello?

question: I'm just calling to make sure you aren't hanging from your shower rod.
answer: You called an hour too early.

question: So, what's the V-day plan?
answer: Miranda and I are going to dinner and then a really violent slasher movie.

question: Perfect.

question: I am making Smith sushi. Pause for reaction.

question: We took a class a while back -- and when he walks in the door at seven- thirty, I am going to surprise him by laying on the dining room table - -- covered with homemade sushi.
answer: Boy, you do have time on your hands.

question: And Miranda... in that article -- I did not say "we" once. It was all
answer: It was from your point of view.

question: My point of view... Exactly. The whole wedding was my point of view. I let the wedding get bigger than Big. I am the reason he didn't get out of that car.

question: What do you mean?
answer: I was really upset after Steve showed up and I bumped into Big and -- I said that you two were crazy to get married.

question: Stop -- It's fine -- Thanks. I'm sorry, I was upset-- Steve had--

question: I tried to tell you once but the Vogue article came out --
answer: Once? You tried to tell me once? You should have tried to tell me every single day!

question: I know, I was looking for the right time.
answer: There is no right time to tell me you ruined my marriage!

question: It just happened -- I wasn't thinking. Carrie, please -- Don't go -- I --
answer: And I think what hurts the most is that you kept a secret from me. I have never ever kept a secret from you. Ever! No, I'm lying. For the last five months I've been thinking that it's a huge mistake that you left Steve. There. How does it feel? Excuse me!

question: I'm home! Man, that was a long day -- the crew went into double overtime.
answer: You are three hours late.

question: Bummer. I know. Did you eat?
answer: Yes, I ate. I ate the sushi that I hand made for you. The sushi that I planned to lay all over my naked body as a Valentines surprise for you.

question: Why are you so upset? I called.
answer: I slaved away in a kitchen all day to make this meal for you.

question: You made some sushi -- it's not a big deal!
answer: Not a big deal? You see this -- This took me five fucking hours! I am not the type of woman who sits home all day waiting for a man! You love California so much -- enjoy your hand-made California roll!

question: It's me. Pick up. Are you there?
answer: Three days of "I'm sorry" calls and e-mails and flowers -- and I still wasn't ready. It was the longest we'd even gone without speaking.

question: Carrie. Hi. I need to talk to you.
answer: How long have you been waiting here?

question: Seventeen dollars long. Please get in. It just turned to eighteen.
answer: I'm upset.

question: Carrie, I understand -- but it just happened -- I never meant to hurt you. You have to forgive me.
answer: You know --

question: What?
answer: No.

question: Please. What were you going to say?
answer: You badger me to forgive you in three days -- and you won't even consider forgiving Steve for something he did six months ago.

question: It's not the same thing.
answer: It's forgiveness. And -- I know you're not the reason my marriage fell apart. I was just - desperate to have someone else to blame.

question: I don't know if I can trust that it won't happen again.
answer: Miranda, I know I made it hard for you to trust me. But -- You made it hard for me to trust you.

question: Me?!
answer: The way you treated me and cut me out of your life like that? I mean, yeah -- I broke a vow. But what about the other vows? Like promising to love someone for better or for worse? What about that? How do I know she won't punish me for the rest of my life?

question: So, we're done with our last session and we're not allowed to talk for two weeks while we figure out if being together again is something we really want. And then - - we had to pick a place to meet -- and if we both show up on that day - - the past no longer exists. Showing up is the promise we make to each other that we're willing to let it all go and move forward.
answer: Can you do that?

question: I don't know. I have a lot of thinking to do.
answer: Thinking -- or feeling?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Miranda -- you're a lawyer. You can argue both sides of any case -- but, why we feel what we feel -- isn't logical. It's emotional. Sorry, Harvard -- I'm afraid you're going to have to make this decision based on your emotions.

question: Well, then -- I'm screwed. I don't know what I feel.
answer: You will. There will come a moment when you'll know. And if it's

question: And I thought picking the place to meet was a challenge.
answer: Where is it?

question: The Brooklyn Bridge. Halfway between both our places.
answer: Very logical. And yet poetic.

question: I have two pieces of good news.
answer: And I have two coffees.

question: I just got a heads-up from your realtor. The apartment on Fifth finally sold. You have sixty days before the new owner takes possession and you are out of there.
answer: What's the other news? Oh my God --

question: I'm moving back to St. Louis -- we are getting married in the fall.
answer: Meanwhile, back in Lost Angeles... ... Samantha had money, a career and a man who loved her... Still, she couldn't shake the feeling that something was missing from her life.

question: Everything except Dante's dick.
answer: Language, please -- this is a grown- up apartment now.

question: I guess I didn't realize how big I was until I saw it on your faces.
answer: How -- and I say this with love -- How could you not realize it?

question: I don't know if there's anything to be proud of. I stuff my face to stop myself from doing something that feels natural to me.
answer: Why didn't you say something?

question: I guess I didn't want to admit it. And when you're in denial -- you don't dial.
answer: Now, listen -- this isn't about the weight. You'd be gorgeous at any size. But are you happy?

question: Relationships aren't always about being happy, right? How often do you feel happy in your relationship?
answer: I'm pretty sure that's to you.

question: Hey -- You're home! I thought you were staying the week.
answer: We need to talk.

question: Awwww... man. I knew this was coming.
answer: Yeah. This isn't working. I've done my best. I've given it five years and fifteen pounds.

question: What -- You don't love me any more?
answer: Yes, I love you - ah, fuck it -- I'm just gonna say the thing you're not supposed to say -- I love you but I love me more. And I've been in a relationship with myself for forty-nine years and that's the one I need to work on. You'll find a wonderful woman who loves being in a relationship.

question: What will you find?
answer: I don't know. But that's a risk I'm willing to take. No. I'm keeping this. Every time I look down at it I want to think of you.

question: As someone returned to my life... ... Someone left.
answer: And I put all the unopened mail from your P.O. Box in the manila envelopes on the bottom shelf there. And please -- please do not make a mess of CarrieBradshaw.com -- it's my masterpiece.

question: What am I gonna do without you?
answer: You'll find some other girl... but she won't have my style.

question: St. Louise, you brought me back to life.
answer: And you gave me Louise Vuitton. Serious. We need to stop cryin'. Your keys.

question: Wait -- don't forget your "love."
answer: No, I found my love. I'm leaving that with you. See you at my wedding.

question: No, I'm sorry -- I can't stay -- Help me -- pull out the table. I can't --
answer: Charlotte. Charlotte wait -- You're pregnant -- don't run.

question: I don't want to see you. I'm so mad at you. I was always on your side and then you did that to Carrie -- No, no -- I'm not going to cry -- I'm not going to waste tears on you -- I curse the day you were born! I think my water just broke. Oh my God -- Taxi!
answer: My car's right there. Get in my car.

question: I don't want to get in your car -- I hate your car. Taxi!
answer: Charlotte -- we need to get you to the hospital -- Please get in my car. It's right here and ready.

question: Well -- today is not about him. It's about beautiful baby Rose. So -- we know she has Charlotte's hair -- what else do we know? She's a doll. Mazel tov!
answer: He asked me to ask you to call him. I know! It's none of my business. But I felt bad for the poor schmuck hanging around the hospital waiting room hoping to see you. I swear every time he heard someone in heels coming down the hall -- his heart stopped.

question: Harry -- it's so much more complicated than you can imagine.
answer: I know it is -- and you have every right to never call him -- but I'm just a big pile of love today --and I feel bad for the guy. He said he's been writing you -- but you never responded.

question: He's never written me.
answer: He said he wrote because he didn't have your phone number.

question: No. He's never written me. Ever.
answer: Then, why would he say that he had?

question: Two hours, two manila envelopes and countless emails later, I was just about to give up on the Big riddle when -- I had told Louise to put Big in a place where I would never have to hear from him again. Hey, Louise -- it's me. What's the password to get into your assistant file? Call me. Shit. Oh my God. As soon as I typed in "love" -- there he was. And because Big still didn't have the words... he retyped a love letter from Beethoven. And Lord Byron. And James Joyce. And Voltaire. There they were. "The Love Letters of Great Men - Volume One." Plus one more... Written by John James Preston. I wanted to call him - but our love... Carrie and Big Hello.
answer: I didn't hear my phone. We are shopping for my wedding gown. Momma -- can you please -- This is a work call.

question: No, it's okay I figured it out.
answer: Well, I was going to call you anyway -- today is the final day on the Fifth Avenue apartment. You have till six before they change the locks.

question: I don't need to go over there.
answer: And do you NOT want those never- worn shoes?

question: Oh -- I completely forgot about --
answer: `Cause if you don't -- send them on to me. I'll squeeze my feet into them.

question: It's already five o'clock.
answer: Hello? There are never been worn four hundred dollar shoes!

question: Five twenty-five. Bye. Taxi! The light in our pre-war apartment looked completely different post- war.
answer: I was going to get these to you. I didn't want it to be a total loss.

question: It wasn't logic -- it was love. Why did we ever decide to get married?
answer: I guess we were afraid it meant something if we didn't. I'm sorry to have done that to you.

question: I'm sorry to have done that to you... And you know the funny part?
answer: Is there a funny part?

question: We were perfectly happy before we decided to live happily ever after.
answer: Yep. The jokes on us.

question: Good closet.
answer: Thanks.

question: Comfortable. Is this what you had in mind when you installed the carpet?
answer: I'd like to think I was that smooth.

question: We better get up before the new owner bust in on us.
answer: And the way we decided to get married -- All business... No romance. That's not the way you propose to someone. This is. Carrie Bradshaw -- love of my life - - will you marry me? See, this is why there's a diamond. You need to do something to close the deal.

question: And in the end... Carrie Bradshaw married John James Preston in a label-less dress.
answer: Ever thine. Ever mine. Ever ours. You okay that it was just us?

question: Perfect. You and me -- like I said.
answer: Still. Would have been nice if you had the girls here. Which is why I called them.
